abstract.p: Letter from Dr Judith Ebenstein, psychiatrist, says overeaters should be shown that exercise and healthy diet create sense of heightened well-being

block.p: Re ''The Fat Epidemic'' series (Oct. 12, 17, 18, 19): Human beings do not eat simply because they are hungry or because their genes so instruct them. They eat because they like the taste, because they are socializing, because they are upset and because they feel they deserve the reward of extra calories.

Re ''The Fat Epidemic'' series (Oct. 12, 17, 18, 19): Human beings do not eat simply because they are hungry or because their genes so instruct them. They eat because they like the taste, because they are socializing, because they are upset and because they feel they deserve the reward of extra calories.

Your description of the painful self-discipline associated with weight control implies an unstated assumption -- that the absence of this reward inevitably results in an unhappy life. The road of perceived deprivation leads directly from obsession to binge eating.

As a psychiatrist who specializes in eating disorders, I try to teach my patients that exercise and a healthy diet create a sense of heightened well-being, not the reverse. Why must feeling trim and healthy, unencumbered by the fatigue of a diet laced in fat, be viewed as loss?
JUDITH EBENSTEIN, M.D. Irvington, N.Y., Oct. 19, 2000
